ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned to write a research paper and better write an academic paper with a problem, claim, and warrants.

i think i became a better writer? lukas was pretty bad at explaining his critiques so there were many times where i didnt understand what he meant by certain concepts or how i could improve my paper/writing in general
Basics about how to write and craft a college level paper.
I felt that my writing improved greatly through this course.
Learned how to write a papers.

I feel like I was pretty well prepared from my high school in terms of general paper writing but I think this class really moved me to a college level of writing. Also, I learned about a lot of really interesting contemporary and past social movements that I had never heard of before.
I learned a lot about past protests. It was very informative and good information to know.
Writing, reading short texts

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I thought the readings for the course were interesting and well-selected. However, expectations for the course were not always made clear and concepts (problem, claim, warrants) were often explained in a confusing way. The readings held a lot of potential for exciting conversation but class discussions often fell short.

I understand that this course is a writing seminar, but I did not think it focused enough on the topic of the course. It was titled "What does protest look like?" and although we had readings focused on protest, we never really discussed the content of the readings in class. It had good information on writing skills, but I found the class time to be weak in that we went in circles answering rather general questions instead of delving deep into questions of cause and effects of protests talked about in the readings.
different professor
It was interesting to learn from other writers, however I felt that that class could use a little bit more structure.
This class was helpful for writing, but sometimes what the professor wanted was very ambiguous and confusing making it more difficult to write our papers.
Professor was very unclear about everything.

I think the topic of this class was fascinating and the autonomy we had over most of our paper topics was really nice. However, I feel like a lot of the class time got bogged down in arguing and analyzing the structures of papers which we never fully grasped. Paper structures weren't clearly explained and I think we all got lost in trying to name specific things that we didn't understand.

The course is very well designed to help freshman become stronger writers. It is very well laid out, constantly working on papers really improved my writing technique.

The course's main weakness was Professor Moe. He was very confusing. The other students and I would often discuss how confusing he was and how little we got out of every class. After attending class and his office hours, we would usually leave more confused about terms like "warrant" or how to improve our papers than when we arrived.
Readings are not relevant to the writings

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I probably would not recommend this course to a friend, because I didn't feel it improved my writing significantly, and I often left class confused and frustrated by  the lack of clear feedback and instruction.
no. take an ENGL class with an actual professor who will actually give you clear feedback on how to improve your writing
Yes, I would.
No, take a different engl seminar.

I would not recommend this course to another student because if one is looking to learn more about the actual art of protesting, this course does not cover it much. Additionally, it did not really help with improving my writing as a student due to the poor feedback I received from my professor.

I think with some changes relative to the strengths and weaknesses section I answered earlier, this would be a great class that I would definitely recommend. It's really interesting in theory but I think some changes in class structure would benefit the course a lot.

I would recommend the course, but not the professor. Professor Moe was a nightmare. Consistently writing papers probably improved my writing, Professor Moe did not. Definitely take the course to improve your writing, just steer clear of Professor Moe at all costs.
No it is not very interesting

extras.title:
ENGL 114 30
        What Does Protest Look Like?
